217825: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.author: MagicCritic
217825: Elspeth, Knight-Errant.text_parsed:
Beautiful art, Elspeth never ceases to dispapoint.
Comes in T4 for 4 mana for 4 p/t. Comes in quite early in the game.
+1 is so easily abused. Like Sorin's, you will soon have many tokens at your bay.
+1 is good for getting rid of monsters that progressively get stronger (stromkrik, at say 3/3) or you just want to deal big. Usually good for finishing games off.
-8 Ult comes in in 4 turns but is so overpowered. If your opponent is stupid and leaves Elspeth alive, she will keep all your permanents alive and nothing will stop her. Not Breaking Point, not Bonfire of the Damned. Nothing.

217826: Tezzeret the Seeker.author: Flyheight
217826: Tezzeret the Seeker.text_parsed:
@Nessin
Hell yes. Use it to find Everflowing Chalice.

This review is for the Tezzeret deck from Elspeth v. Tezzeret as a whole, b/c there is nowhere to rate this bombastically powerful preconstructed deck:
Wow Wizards, just wow. I picked up the EvT duel deck a while back but hadn't played with them until this past weekend. The Tezzeret deck is just sick, it's a disgustingly powerful casual deck. The combination of everflowing chalice and contagion clasp is just absurd, and with Tezz on the board it's really easy to proliferate twice per turn b/c that chalice is going to be over 4 counters in no time, essentially making the clasp's prolif effect free.

This deck has so many amazing synergistic pieces for it to play with and the best part of it (worst for your opponent) is that it's all in blue so you can dig, dig, dig for everything:

Diggers:
Trinket Mage
Faerie Mechanist
Runed Servitor x2
Thoughtcast (affinity ugh....)
Thirst for Knowledge x2 (b-b-b-b-busted)
Tezzeret the Seeker (big man toolbox himself)
Aether Spellbomb


That's 9 diggers in a 60 card deck...and the Tezz is freakin' repeatable!
Between the Trinket Mage and the two Everflowing Chalices, by the time you get Tezz out you should probably already have a Chalice. At which point you just tutor for the stupid Contagion Clasp and let the insanity begin! Just alternate turns tutoring for stuff and untapping your Clasp and Chalice and in no time at all (maybe 2-3 turns) you have an extremely well oiled engine pumping out counters and tokens and cards like nobody's business! They really should have given the Elspeth deck an Austere Command or something to level the playing field. (lose the craptastic Rustic Clachan)


Tezzeret the Seeker: 4.5/5
Tezzeret duel deck: 4/5 (casual)

218340: Mishra's Factory.author: EvilCleavage
218340: Mishra's Factory.text_parsed:
I can't believe that I got this card finally!! I had to buy three Dual Decks and trade a buddy to get 4 of these! But it was sooo worth it! Not bad for sixty bucks eh? 3 Elspeth's, 3 Tezzeret's, 3 Mishra's Factories, 6 Swords to Plowshares, 3 Master of Etheriums, 3 Steel Overseers, 3 Loyal Sentry's, 3 Crusade's, a few Foil's, artifact lands, and a couple other rares and good uncommons and commons. Shoot, I probably missed a few cards.

BUY THIS DECK IF YOU CAN! IT IS SERIOUSLY ONE OF THE BEST DEALS OUT THERE. $20.00 baby.

But anyways, this card is seriously a classic that is always good! Personally, I play the four of these I have in a Control and it's awesome because it doesn't die to mass removal. Just play your Day of Judgment's or Wrath of God's and then hit 'em next turn or even the same turn with a couple of these and a Celestial Collonade. This card wasn't used for years and years in tourney's for no reason.

218340: Mishra's Factory.author: tcollins
218340: Mishra's Factory.text_parsed:
Blocks as a 3/3 if you're doing it right. I love how it is so versatile, it can:

1. Avoids sorcery mass removal
2. Beat face in control decks (as with most other manlands)
3. Blocks for you
4. Enables combo cards based on artifacts such as Tinker and on creatures such as Polymorph
5. Prevents your opponents from "forcing" you to sacrifice a creature (provided it is untapped)

I also enjoy how it fit's into almost any deck I make, and performs flawlessly in almost all of them.

218340: Mishra's Factory.author: DarthParallax
218340: Mishra's Factory.text_parsed:
The only thing that ever bugged me was this: I've tried to figure out how Melvin-y this card is, and what I come up with is that you should ignore that this taps for mana, correct?

In order to use both of its other abilities to the best possible efficiency, you need a second land to make the mana to activate it's animation ability so it can still tap to give itself +1/+1.

I'm irritated at how long it took me to figure this out, because for such a hyped card that I'm too young to have played against the original version of, I kept expecting it to have everything it needed by itself. :P This doesn't really detract from other people's evaluations of it though. :) It's definitely a powerful land.

I am wondering though-- if Urza's Factory is overpriced and Mishra's Factory is underpriced, how much mana do think would be fair to make an Assembly Worker? 3? 4?

218580: Thirst for Knowledge.author: zk3
218580: Thirst for Knowledge.text_parsed:
Guest: Actually, you're right in thinking that this card isn't on par with other vintage restricted draw spells. However, the reason this card was so good was because it powered up an entire deck archetype. It was THE main draw engine of Tezzeret decks for a while, when Time Vault + Voltaic Key was their main win condition.
It also helped Goblin Welder decks dig deeper and discard their welding target.

The fact that it was a 4-of in these decks gave them an incredible draw engine that clearly set them above all other decks at the time. Tournaments were very lopsided, as decks built with this card almost always outclasses decks without. Thus, as wizards restricted this card out of metagame considerations - to balance out the tournament scene.

218582: Crusade.author: SquareHippy
218582: Crusade.text_parsed:
Just so people know, the term "strictly better" can only refer to cards that either have directly comparable text and different costs to the point where one is more optimal than the other, or where two cards have the exact same cost and one has text that makes it superior to the other, and it judges cards in a vacuum. The existence of Muraganda Pietroglyphs does not stop Ashcoat Bear from being strictly better than Grizzly Bears. If you need more examples of what the term means, look at this: http://wiki.mtgsalvation.com/article/Strictly_better

Crusade is strictly worse than Honor of the Pure. Get over it.
218582: Crusade.text_posted:
Just so people know, the term "strictly better" can only refer to cards that either have directly comparable text and different costs to the point where one is more optimal than the other, or where two cards have the exact same cost and one has text that makes it superior to the other, and it judges cards in a vacuum. The existence of [autocard]Muraganda Pietroglyphs[/autocard] does not stop [autocard]Ashcoat Bear[/autocard] from being strictly better than [autocard]Grizzly Bears[/autocard]. If you need more examples of what the term means, look at this: http://wiki.mtgsalvation.com/article/Strictly_better

Crusade is strictly worse than Honor of the Pure. Get over it.

218582: Crusade.text_posted: I liked the old art better, when you could see the burning smoke of recently sacked Constantinople.

218582: Crusade.author: blurrymadness
218582: Crusade.text_parsed:
EDIT: Something to note here. Strictly better also often needs to be qualified. The attached link defining strictly better is:
A- on a wiki, so is unreliable/not proven knowledge (I.E. i can just go edit it right now, printscreen, and forever be just as semi correct as those citing it. It's just an approximation, like a book report on a book.)
B- The statements here are not qualified like those on the wiki either. You MUST put cards in a vacuum if you want to claim "strictly better" in nearly all circumstances.


(Were this made today and not way back in Alpha) something to keep in mind is that it'd likely be made *for* multiplayer white games, heck, the flavor works best there!

Benefits over Honor of the Pure:
-Opponents can't steal it to take away your bonus. It must be bounced/destroyed/exiled
-Multiplayer shinanigans
-White destroy cards that check power certainly have synergy with this
-as well as white "doesn't untap" cards that check power level
-chroma (this card is spectacular with spring jack shepard. Get two of these out and him, get 5 2/3's and a 3/4 for a total of 8 mana)
-cards that redirect damage

Cons by comparison:
-could beef up enemies creatures
-less splashability

Restating one of my original points, run this in white weenie and even if you beef up a thoctar by 1, or some other naya creature, it's not like your +3/+3 spread among your tokens is worth all the less. Were I running white weenie, i'd take advantage of chroma, power-level checkers, and run both this AND honor of the pure. Easy Peasy.
218582: Crusade.text_posted:
EDIT: Something to note here. Strictly better also often needs to be qualified. The attached link defining strictly better is: 
A- on a wiki, so is unreliable/not proven knowledge (I.E. i can just go edit it right now, printscreen, and forever be just as semi correct as those citing it. It's just an approximation, like a book report on a book.)
B- The statements here are not qualified like those on the wiki either. You MUST put cards in a vacuum if you want to claim "strictly better" in nearly all circumstances.

218582: Crusade.author: DarthParallax
218582: Crusade.text_parsed:
To Vorthoses, Crusade is strictly better than Honor of the Pure.

Crusade pumps enemy creatures, yes. To Vorthos, that's a bonus. You are clearly starting a Holy War, and your opponents' clerics get to get in on that. I'm running Knights with protection from your, protection from your friend, and protection from your grandma's pet dog, so that's not really a problem for me.

Crusade also costs instead of . This also is better in Vorthos' opinion, because it shows how you have to have a strong commitment to the color to get this sort of inspired. You run this in a mono-white deck, a white-centric shard or wedge deck, or a W/x classic two-color build... but you are NOT getting away with white as your off color here. You gotta mean it.

Yes, these are technically 'drawbacks'. But they are also meaningful elements of the card that make it much more evocative than HotP, which is just out-and-out blatant power creep. I understand and like the idea of the new one-sided approach to lords. Even though I can think of a cool reason why this particular card really should break the pattern and pump your opponent's creatures, most people will not want a card that does that. Fine.

I do think it's a serious mistake to lighten the color requirements on the card. Especially considering the one-sidedness factor. Honor of the Pure should cost . Not because is broken, but because it changes something that doesn't need to be changed, and the old saying 'if it's not broke, don't fix it' is something Wizards hasn't been paying enough attention to recently. Pushing some things is cool. Pushing others is not. HotP does a disservice to Crusade by existing, and Crusade didn't even need to be made better in the first place.

222707: Razormane Masticore.author: blurrymadness
222707: Razormane Masticore.text_parsed:
Difficult to judge. He's obviously a powerhouse due to the First Strike and the lightning bolts are brutal.

It depends on the deck whether this or another Masticore will treat you well. The others have regenerate, which is a big deal; however, they'll often actually need it where as this guy will take a 5+/6+ blocker that you *didn't* bolt to stop him; so it's hard to say. The others support a strategy of dumping all your mana into them; but it's supposed to be fine since you're losing cards. This guy doesn't give you a use for your mana, but is efficient without it.

I imagine that this is the best tournament wise, with the others also being quite dangerous.

three in total. THREE.
Mosquito Guard, Goldmeadow Harrier and Burreton Bombardier.
Two of them are one-drops, so even if you got one of these in your opening hand and draw this land in your second turn, this will very likely find its way into play tapped.

I have four ássumptions how this card got strayed into this deck:

1. Wizards had this card wrong in mind and thought it was a tribal land for Soldier decks -since most Kithkin decks were centered around Kithkin Soldiers.
2. At some point of deck development, there were more Kithkin in this deck than there are in it's current state, and they somehow forgot about this card.
3. Wizard knows that some players would love to see rare lands in the preconstructed decks, so they wanted to do them a favor and fulfil their wish...to some extent.
4. Wizards thought having two Swords to Plowshares gives the necessity for a bad rare slot, so they decided this card might just the right one.

Maybe all ássumtions bear a little truth in them, but overall i'm pretty sure they did it
for the lulz.

If Wizards urgently wanted something Kithkin-related to take in the rare slot, i'd have prefered Preeminent Captain, or Militia's Pride.

Sadly, this card is meant for a Kithkin deck, not a Soldier deck.

222717: Rustic Clachan.author: GrimjawxRULES
222717: Rustic Clachan.text_parsed:
I hate that this card is in the Elspeth deck. All I've experienced with this card is the "enters the battlefield tapped" part. Reinforce is good, don't misunderstand me, but this card has no place in a deck that has anything less than 20 kithkins in it!

I'm pretty disappointed about the balance issues with this duel deck. I mean, just take a look at the rares, and you'll see that Tezzeret's deck has all the gamebreakers while Elspeth's deck has ... what ... Crusade? Oh wait, Tezzeret's deck has Steel Overseer.
Even Contagion Clasp beats Kemba's Skyguard.

If you look at the individual decks, you'll see that Tezzeret's deck has loads of synergies, especially with Energy Chamber and Steel Overseer, but also Pentavus + Tezzeret's ultimate, or Razormane Masticore's discard + Argivian Restoration. Also, Qumulox is just overpowered when you take into consideration that the only flying creature in Elspeth's deck large enough to take it down is yet another so-so rare (in my opinion), namely Angel of Salvation.

222733: Arcbound Worker.author: mrsgromlin
222733: Arcbound Worker.text_parsed: That ruling has to be incorrect now. Since Shadowmoor introduced the +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters cancelling each other out as a state-based effect, there would be no +1/+1 counters on this guy to move.
222733: Arcbound Worker.text_posted: That ruling has to be incorrect now. Since Shadowmoor introduced the +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters cancelling each other out as a state-based effect, there would be no +1/+1 counters on this guy to move.

222733: Arcbound Worker.author: JaxsonBateman
222733: Arcbound Worker.text_parsed: That's not true - the ruling is correct. If a creature with +1/+1 counters receives enough -1/-1 counters to reduce its toughness to 0 IN ONE GO (ie. Arcbound Worker is hit with a Distill Infection), then two state based actions are checked at the same time the next time a player gains priority: a creature with toughness 0 being sent to the graveyard, and +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters cancelling each other out. As the creature is sent to the graveyard at the same time the counters would be cancelled out the game still sees it as having had an appropriate number of +1/+1 counters, and as such they can be moved via modular.
222733: Arcbound Worker.text_posted: That's not true - the ruling is correct. If a creature with +1/+1 counters receives enough -1/-1 counters to reduce its toughness to 0 IN ONE GO (ie. Arcbound Worker is hit with a Distill Infection), then two state based actions are checked at the same time the next time a player gains priority: a creature with toughness 0 being sent to the graveyard, and +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters cancelling each other out. As the creature is sent to the graveyard at the same time the counters would be cancelled out the game still sees it as having had an appropriate number of +1/+1 counters, and as such they can be moved via modular.

222735: Echoing Truth.author: Stray_Dog
222735: Echoing Truth.text_parsed:
Ok this card definitely rocks the casbah, but I am trying to see how it could be updated for inclusion in modern play. By updated, I mean better-balanced.

It isn't just token-hating that makes this card rock (although the ability to destroy mass tokens should be uncommon at least). Most competitive deckbuilders these days run four-ofs as a general rule, so it is quite common to see two or more of the same creature/artifact/enchantment on the battlefield. This makes the card a 'two for one' tempo disruptor on a fairly regular basis, and compared to cards like Disperse, that is probably too good.

Granted, the card can have the negative side effect of making you bounce your own creatures in some rare scenarios, but that isn't really worth taking into consideration as a cost-cutting drawback -more like just an interesting quirk of the card that will show up from time to time.

First thought is that the card should be uncommon, and the mana cost should be raised to . I thought about (2 cmc) but it would still be too easy to use, considering it means almost certain death to token decks (like Eldrazi tokens in standard). at sorcery speed could work, but it would be abandoning one of the trademarks of bounce (and tempo disruption in general): doing it in the opponent's turn. It would turn the card into more of a niche token-hater that isn't splashable, which would be something of a loss I feel.

What if you could bring back the card as is, but make it rare? Bounce feels a little flimsy at rare level though. What do you think?

Another option is to make a rare creature that costs 5+ CMC and has an Echoing Truth-style ETB ability.
Could be cool flavour too... like a 'master' version of AEther Adept ^_^
I particularly like this approach, because the idea mentioned before would probably discourage most people from using an Echoing Truth-style card over Disperse. However, if it came with a powerful creature attached then people would want to use it.

I don't think you would want to make a new version of this card with a different name if you could avoid it, because then it would be possible to have 8 copies of the effect in your deck. That might not be as bad as I fear it would be, though -I don't know alot about eternal formats.

If you are wondering why I have rambled on so much about this, its because I really, really want to use something like Echoing Truth in a standard/extended deck. I love cards that do what I call 'four-copy hate', that is, they hate on players who just resort to the boring old 'play four copies of every powerful card you can fit in' approach.

222740: Seat of the Synod.author: OmegaSerris
222740: Seat of the Synod.text_parsed:
Flavorwise, these made a lot of sense. I shouldn't have to mention Mirrodin's artifact theme. I mean, all of Mirrodin is metal. So why wouldn't it's lands be seen as artifacts? It was mechanically that they screwed up. The problem is that MTG is one part game and one part story (flavor). These helped tell the story, but in combination with the other cards of the set, branded it as MTG's most broken set.

I don't think that these are all that bad on their own. I mean, they have their own weaknesses (Shatter-able for ). It was affinity that was the f*ck up. Affinity for artifacts on Mirrodin would have been like affinity for land on Zendikar. I think Ravanica's Convoke ability was well done. But sadly, it suffered from the aftershock of Mirrodin (as did many sets) and was never pushed to the limits it could have on fear of repeating history.
222740: Seat of the Synod.text_posted:
Flavorwise, these made a lot of sense. I shouldn't have to mention Mirrodin's artifact theme. I mean, all of Mirrodin is metal. So why wouldn't it's lands be seen as artifacts? It was mechanically that they screwed up. The problem is that MTG is one part game and one part story (flavor). These helped tell the story, but in combination with the other cards of the set, branded it as MTG's most broken set.

I don't think that these are all that bad on their own. I mean, they have their own weaknesses ([autocard]Shatter[/autocard]-able for [1R]). It was affinity that was the f*ck up. Affinity for artifacts on Mirrodin would have been like affinity for land on Zendikar. I think Ravanica's Convoke ability was well done. But sadly, it suffered from the aftershock of Mirrodin (as did many sets) and was never pushed to the limits it could have on fear of repeating history.

222748: Celestial Crusader.author: DarthParallax
222748: Celestial Crusader.text_parsed:
This might be one of my favorite white creatures, ever. It gives what you wanted out of Benalish Knight. This is the ultimate in 'ATTENTION ORCS- THE TIDE HAS TURNED. YOU ARE NOW SCREWED.' cards :D

I like the idea of throwing in Knight Exemplars to guard each other, in an otherwise non Knight deck. The result is your Knight Exemplars feel very special, like an elite four man commando team that is brutal together, but without making your entire army feel like it's made of undercosted tanks.

I actually hate the idea of White Tribal- it feels a little too stromtrooper-y (bunch of faceless dorks) for me. Instead, I'll mix up Soldiers, Knights, Spirits, and Angels together to make a really badass looking Alliance. White has cards like Honor of the Pure to let you play with the same power of other colors' tribes, without having to share a creature type to get bonuses. You can definitely pull of the flavor of a white community while at the same time keeping the team diverse, ready for anything. Fish, Gobbys, and Elves may be fast, but compared to the full potential of white creatures they are incredibly short-sighted and narrow-minded tribes. Well, except merfolk. Those guys are just assholes.

Also he hes going to tap his creature and i go and try and use this card in response to him taping his creature to use an ability on the creature would that work or would his creatures ability still go off.
222759: Trip Noose.text_posted: I have a question about this card if lets say someone is using an ability on  a creature and i decide that I'm going to tap him before he tap his creature can he tap his creature in response to me trying to use this card to tap his creature. Also he hes going to tap his creature and i go and try and use this card in response to him taping his creature to use an ability on the creature would that work or would his creatures ability still go off.

222759: Trip Noose.author: GrimjawxRULES
222759: Trip Noose.text_parsed:
@wintersrage: If your opponent activates an activated ability that has in its cost, you can't respond to it by tapping that permanent. Well, you can, but you won't gain anything from it. This is because tapping the permanent is part of the cost to put the ability on the stack - not part of the ability itself.

Lets take Prodigal Pyromancer as an example. It has an activated ability with in its cost.
Now, you tap Prodigal Pyromancer and let its activated ability go on the stack. I could respond to it with Twiddle targeting the Pyromancer, but since the Pyromancer is already tapped, and its activated ability is already on the stack, I wouldn't gain anything from it.
As a rule of thumb: if your goal is to prevent an activated ability from going off, tapping the permanent in response is generally not the way to do it.
222759: Trip Noose.text_posted:
@wintersrage: If your opponent activates an activated ability that has [T] in its cost, you can't respond to it by tapping that permanent. Well, you can, but you won't gain anything from it. This is because tapping the permanent is part of the cost to put the ability on the stack - not part of the ability itself.

Lets take [autocard]Prodigal Pyromancer[/autocard] as an example. It has an activated ability with [T] in its cost.
Now, you tap [autocard]Prodigal Pyromancer[/autocard] and let its activated ability go on the stack. I [i]could[/i] respond to it with [autocard]Twiddle[/autocard] targeting the Pyromancer, but since the Pyromancer is already tapped, and its activated ability is already on the stack, I wouldn't gain anything from it.
As a rule of thumb: if your goal is to prevent an activated ability from going off, tapping the permanent in response is generally not the way to do it.

222761: Journey to Nowhere.author: thekenghiskhan
222761: Journey to Nowhere.text_parsed:
Is there a difference between "Target creature becomes exiled" and "Exile target creature?" The only reason I'm asking is because my friend keeps telling me that cards like Journey to Nowhere that are worded like the latter phrase still has an affect on creatures with things like Shroud, which I feel like is incorrect. I've been giving him the benefit of the doubt because he's a really enthusiastic player who plays quite frequently and I'm a real casual player who doesn't play consistently and really keep up with changing rules.

When Alara block came out I was actually still going off of 7th Ed. rules and thought "Mana Burn" still existed. <--Yea I'm that out of the loop sometimes. So if any of you well seasoned players can clarify this to me I'd really appreciate it.
222761: Journey to Nowhere.text_posted:
Is there a difference between "Target creature becomes exiled" and "Exile target creature?"  The only reason I'm asking is because my friend keeps telling me that cards like Journey to Nowhere that are worded like the latter phrase still has an affect on creatures with things like Shroud, which I feel like is incorrect.  I've been giving him the benefit of the doubt because he's a really enthusiastic player who plays quite frequently and I'm a real casual player who doesn't play consistently and really keep up with changing rules.

222761: Journey to Nowhere.author: count_dorku
222761: Journey to Nowhere.text_parsed: Thekenghiskhan: Your friend is wrong. If it has shroud, nobody can target it. Full stop. "Target creature is exiled" still targets a creature, so shroud defends against it quite admirably.
222761: Journey to Nowhere.text_posted: Thekenghiskhan: Your friend is wrong. If it has shroud, nobody can target it. Full stop. "Target creature is exiled" still targets a creature, so shroud defends against it quite admirably.

@thekenghiskhan
If the ability had said "Exile one creature", you could have exiled a creature with shroud (or color protection). But it says "target" permanent, both of the situations you mentioned requires you to target a creature, a shrouded creature is untargetable.
222761: Journey to Nowhere.text_posted:

If the ability had said "Exile one creature", you could have exiled a creature with shroud (or color protection). But it says "target" permanent, both of the situations you mentioned requires you to target a creature, a shrouded creature is untargetable.

222761: Journey to Nowhere.author: crimson_sunrise
222761: Journey to Nowhere.text_parsed:
I like this card very much. It's unfortunate that it looks quite similar to Oblivion Ring and that the latter can deal with planeswalkers - that means that designers are probably going to prefer to keep Oblivion Ring around in core sets, and it'd be nice to see this card get a second chance in Standard. On the other hand, if someone ever makes another efficient card that can deal with planeswalkers, it might take Oblivion Ring's place for a rotation.

Until then, there's casual play.

222764: Kor Skyfisher.author: Diab0l0
222764: Kor Skyfisher.text_parsed:
2/3 Flying for 2 is quite above the curve.
You really should NOT read the "return a permanent" triggered ability as an inconvenient. It is a great advantage if you build around it.

If you miss a land drop and can cast this guy, It's a 2/3 flying for in practice!
Any landfall deck can certainly benefit from this ability.

I use it in a mono white control deck. You can get serious card advantage with four of these and four Wall of Omens. You can also bounce Kor Sanctifiers if you need to disenchant stuff and considering the sick artifacts (could have linke any sword to...) that are around currently in standard, that can be interesting. It also helps your Kor Cartographer fetch the many plains needed for Emeria, the Sky Ruin. It's just really good when played with any creatures with "comes into play" abilities.

It could be funny to use on Contagion Clasp and Contagion Engine to!

I am sure those deck with Squadron Hawk, swords and Stoneforge Mystic wouldn't mind getting an extra flying creature and fetching a second sword with their Mystic by casting it twice. ;)

Five stars for this cheap combo common.

222764: Kor Skyfisher.author: dberry02
222764: Kor Skyfisher.text_parsed:
This card is cheap, has flying and combos really well with a lot of cards! It's even on a solid 2/3 body! This card is an aggro/combo card. It's mainly a white aggro card, but it doubles up as card combo. Most people would see the bounce as a downside, or they would use it as such - they'd bounce something normal.

But when you use this in a bounce combo, it really shines. I've seen people use this alongside with Kabira Crossroads to net life. I personally use it to bounce itself in my lifegain deck. I play Kor Skyfisher alongside with Soul Warden or Angelic Chorus. I just bounce Kor Skyfisher multiple times and end up gaining a lot of life.

This is essentially as good as Whitemane Lion. Instead of flash, you get +1 toughness and gain flying. A very good trade off in my opinion. This card is solid and game winning when used correctly 5/5

Really deserves a >4 Rating.

Disregarding the fact that it's an under-the curve flyer in white, it has almost endless shenanigan potential. Like others have said, you can bounce a land and replay it to have a 2/3 flyer for .

Additionally, it's in a tribe with a lot of ETB effects. Kor Sanctifiers, Stoneforge Mystic and many more like to enter the battlefield several times.

Also works nice with things like Quest for the Holy Relic, letting you add counters for , though admittedly there are better creatures for this purpose.

Overall, the sheer number of applications makes this a solid 4.5/5 in my book.

222766: Foil.author: Travelsonic
222766: Foil.text_parsed:
When talking Foil versus Force of Will, I like how the mana cost seems to be what a few - not everyone, obviously - are harping on.

Sure, for hardcasting, FoW is better.

What about the alternative-to-paying-the-mana-cost?

Would you rather lose life and exile a blue permanent, or discard an island, and another card - a land, a creature with the madness ability, or something that is either useful in the graveyard, can be brought back somehow easily, etc?

Ultimately it depends, I for one don't want to run the risk of losing mana sources just to counter a spell, but from discussions online **in general** I don't think Foil is being given enough credit... sure, it is no FoW, but there **MAY** be potentials I don't think are being realized with this card that you can't necessarily do with FoW directly.

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: Kryptnyt
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed:
Angels are so baffling to me, size-wise. Why do they so often have p/t 5 to 8? Angels rival dragons; dragons have diamond-hard scales, general enormity, and powerful elemental breath attacks. Angels rival demons, who ripple with muscle and sinew, wield cruel weapons, and are often huge in size. Angels are humans with wings, phisiologically. They aren't large, they have no heavy muscle structure, and sometimes they have no weapons. Can't explain this away by saying they are magically enchanted, because the most powerful human wizards in magic are usually 3 or rarely 4 power or toughness. Yet here we have these winged ladies, who (generally) have untoned muscles and weak frames. Of course they have to be 5/6s or 6/7s because White needs a big flying creature, right? I guess so. And its okay if the angel in question is legendary, because if your skill in fighting makes you a 6/6 you'd better be famous. Its just that while Sphinxes, Demons, and Dragons rule the blue, black, and red skies, respectively, and half-naked ladies manage to lay down aerial beats in white, it makes me wonder why we don't have some kind of mythical beast flier evergreen in white. Lammasu? Maybe. Archons? Archons seem like humans too, but they always have a mount of some sort... so they are more acceptable than angels. I say no angel should be greater than 4/4 without showing some serious muscle, having explained skill, or being legendary like Razia or Akroma.
Angel of Salvation is a fine card, in every other way. Flash and Convoke are really excellent together. Flash on damage prevention is necessary if it is a one-shot, and a 5/5 flier package can show up to surprise block and attack right back the next turn. It might be a nice sideboard in an elf deck, depending on if you have elves that are hybrid or something, because you can expect your opponent to side in Pyroclasm or Volcanic Fallout for sure. Don't know any elf decks that use white but I think its a decent option.

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: Exelia
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt
I like playing with angels, so I fully admit I'm biased but... see, there's a difference between looking like a human with wings and being a human with wings. Angels do indeed look like humans with wings, but they are celestial beings, serving a greater power. Seeing as how most angels are white, and the theme of white cards are protection, it follows to reason that angels are protected with divine magic by the being they're serving. Also, judging by many angel abilities, the conclusion that they're bolstered by magic which focuses on improving their prowess in physical combat can be drawn (which is also very white-flavor). Really, it's the same as vampires being more powerful than humans, only they're powered by black magic rather than white.
Also, it can safely be assumed that angels are quite well equipped. They're not fighting with bronze swords and armor, but most likely finely made items from whatever heavenly realm they're coming from. So to me at least, angels being flying powerhouses makes perfect sense.

Gabriel dressed in armor with that hammer looked like he could crush anything in his way with no problem.

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: rulesinquisitor
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed:
@krypnit
Keep in mind, angels don't necessarily have to be average human size. Many MTG angels are depicted without a frame of reference for size. Angel of Salvation itself is depicted against open sky. For all we know, it could be six stories tall. If you ask me, some of the angels on MTG cards are shown in a way that (albeit inconclusively) suggests vast size. (Angelic Arbiter, Deathless Angel, Empyrial Archangel, Iona, Shield of Emeria, Platinum Angel, and Sunblast Angel, to name a few.) Think of the Nephilim -- not the weird MTG ones, but the "real life" ones. Mythical or not, they were "angelic" beings that were colossal compared to humans.

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: Shiizu
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed:
So much whining and complaining for a pretty sweet angel. This creature has always been somewhat underestimated since it deals with damage prevention. Like all creatures that prevent more than one damage, it is actually a real blow-out of a card. It shines the most when you're in a stand-off and when your opponent goes in for some damage, you cast it, prevent most if not all of the incoming damage to you and your creatures, and eat a couple of his threats.
Really, this angel has won me more games than her dragon counterpart simply because she always causes a blow-out. And it's not even such an expensive trick in a board stall.

Oh, and in the elspeth deck, this is one of the few cards that make elspeth survive the long game. It needs no mention that the tezzeret deck will not survive an EOT angel of salvation if it resolves.

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: Mike-C
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed: @ Kryptnyt: Sounds like your debate was ever so slightly bias. Just an observation. So to be fair, so will be mine. Angels are NOT humans w/wings.. Angels resemble humans in the flesh, some of them even once were humans. But to say they ARE human is to say a Vampire is human, or a Werewolf, even a Zombie.. All of whom were USUALLY once human but through death have gained "superhuman" abilities. In this case, be that it's Angels being briefed, those abilities happen to be God given and therefor, of the strongest and most powerful kind. Angels typically represent light, peace and love plus, play for the "GOOD" team. They don't appear scary, powerful or give you a need to be defensive feeling because they don't go looking for trouble, they are guardians of those deserving protection and would normally be seen doing kind acts through the looking glass. But when there's war, and someone who represents "Good" has their back(s) up against the wall, they will show up and when they do, the continued fight is usually a short one. You see, Evil/the Dark side, in all of its lust for greater power has usually sacrificed its soul achieving it. Although almost NEVER the plan, initially, it's almost inevitable and much like a child who's gotten away with 1 too many wrong-doings, Evil actually wants to receive its DESERVED punishment, Angels are the ones who respectfully oblige those deserving :)

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: AMart83
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed:
Rating: 4/5

You can her with 4 lands if you have 4 creatures. In the same scenario, you can block with the four creatures, then tap the creatures + lands to flash her in and divide the 5 damage to save your creatures.

If you flash her in to block, she's essentially a 5/10 blocker if you prevent the first 5 damage to her.

She can be splashed into any deck since you pick the color of mana when tapping a creature you're using to pay cast a card with convoke.

I wish Wizards would print more creature cards with flash + convoke and perhaps ETB abilities.

222774: Angel of Salvation.author: toXicus
222774: Angel of Salvation.text_parsed:
When I was reading the comments about angels just being humans with wings, i kept thinking of the Saint of Killers from the Preacher graphic novels. He looks like a sour old man, but is incredibly powerful, able to take massive amounts of damage without even twitching and able to destroy anything that comes between him and his goals. When I think of an angel in combat I don't ever think of them going up to someone and punching them- if Angel of Salvation fought a bear, the bear would just be incinerated by a column of light. The bear's attacks might weaken her essence a bit, but there wouldn't be a wound or blood or anything else we mortals associate with injuries.
(Also rulesinquisitor, Iona is canonically absolutely massive- if you look really closely in her art you can see people on the rocks floating around her)

222775: Saltblast.author: Asmodi0000
222775: Saltblast.text_parsed:
This card hits what white was missing. With this, white can get rid of just about anything.

Creature removal? Swords to Plowshares and Path to Exile handle that business.
Mass Creature removal? Only the best in the game, with Wraths and Days and all that other madness.
Enchantment and Artifact removal? There's so much, so much...
Mass Enchantment and Artifact removal? Cleanfall, Purity, and Serenity.
Everything except for land removal? Oblivion ring does it all.
Mass Everything except for lands removal? Akroma's Vengeance and Austere command hit everything except for planeswalkers, and planar cleansing takes care of those as well.

And Saltblast allows white to get rid of pesky lands. Good land destruction goes around at about 3 mana, and decent land destruction goes at 4 (and usually can additionally target something like creatures or artifacts). At 5 mana, saltblast can target a fair amount of stuff, even when fighting against a mono-white deck.

And, of course, white had mass land removal with Armageddon.

222775: Saltblast.author: Admiral_Ferret
222775: Saltblast.text_parsed:
At first I laughed hard at this card, almost right out of my binder.. but then I realized.. Wait.. this is awesome! Totally for my (mono-white) angel deck (Where I have 4-9 mana costing angels).. Mana's not really a problem. Yeah I've got 4 oblivion rings, but that doesn't mean I'm going to draw them all, a backup could be really useful.

(Note to the comment about it being worthwhile if it were 2WW .. well yeah.. it'd be even better as a 1 WW or WW, or 1W, or W).. 5 mana to destroy your choice of anything nonwhite is pretty cool. Like the older cards saying "Choose one: (given a few options)" generally cost a little more.. or for green 4 mana will give you the choice to destroy enchantment, artifact, or land...for 1 more, you can choose anything, with the added restricting "nonwhite".

I had my angel deck pretty set, but I think I'm going to throw Saltblast in for a while and see how it runs. If it proves less-than-usefull, I will take it out of my deck and remove this comment, but I think it's a good concept.

4/5 for this one.

222857: Argivian Restoration.author: DarthParallax
222857: Argivian Restoration.text_parsed:
Let's actually unpackage ways to use this card, ok?

It's kind of like Zombify, but only for Artifact Creatures, and cards that only describe returning Creatures to battlefield generally do it better. I *suppose* you could use it like this if you are determined to stay mono-Blue.


To Thirst for Knowledge into Argivian Restoration and wind up with an Artifact Creature on the battlefield at the end of it costs 7 mana. You'd be better off Hardcasting Pentavus.

I KNOW the 'if only it cost 1 mana less' rule is always true, so it should be ignored, but really-- the real estate for good artifacts is generally at 4-6 for an Artifact Creature-- basically the same as a Creature- and that usually means White or Black Magic is better at Reanimating them.

For Equipment, it's a *really* solid 3 or 4. You look at Sword of Fire and Ice's cycle, Lightning Greaves, and Darksteel Plate, and you want your equipment to be about that aggressively costed, so you can play it, then play the creature, then equip the turn the creature attacks.

To Blast Stuff kind of indiscriminately, you have Argentum Armor, Lux Cannon, Legacy Weapon, and something Spine something. These, now these are worth bringing back, but paying 4 mana for it puts you strictly in Commander thinking.

For Mana Artifacts, you compare to Sol Ring for colorless and Coalition Relic for Colored. Bringing back one of these is not in most people's futures, and if you're doing so you are still behind at the end of your turn because you used a valuable spell to do the effect of just playing basic land, so your economy must have been in bad shape.

226716: Stormfront Riders.author: HairlessThoctar
226716: Stormfront Riders.text_parsed:
Wrong.

Tokens are creatures same as anything else.
When they are destroyed they are put into a graveyard, and when they are bounced they do end up in your hand.

As a result of being a token in a zone other than the battlefield, they immediately cease to exist from a rules perspective.

If you cast this, and the only creatures you have are tokens, you bounce two of those tokens, get two new tokens, and the ones in your hand cease to be.

226716: Stormfront Riders.author: Aremath
226716: Stormfront Riders.text_parsed:
@CarlosLiberated: That's not how that works: Aetherplasm's ability triggers when it is declared as a blocker. Just like "whenever attacks" triggers don't trigger for things that are put into play attacking, so "whenever blocks triggers" don't happen when something is put into play blocking step. Both can happen only during the declare attackers and declare blockers steps respectively, and only when blocks and attacks are declared for the combat phase.

The card seems okay (white doesn't get non-angel (read non-rare) flyers that often with the exception of the perennial Serra Angel. The ability seems okay, but a little clunky and a little hard to build around. Unless you're using with powerful ETB abilities, it seems not very good, and even with them, it's extremely mana intensive. It is cool though.
226716: Stormfront Riders.text_posted:
@CarlosLiberated: That's not how that works: [autocard]Aetherplasm[/autocard]'s ability triggers [i]when it is declared as a blocker[/i]. Just like "whenever attacks" triggers don't trigger for things that are put into play attacking, so "whenever blocks triggers" don't happen when something is put into play blocking step. Both can happen only during the declare attackers and declare blockers steps respectively, and only when blocks and attacks are declared for the combat phase.

The card seems okay (white doesn't get non-angel (read non-rare) flyers that often with the exception of the perennial [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard]. The ability seems okay, but a little clunky and a little hard to build around. 227149: Contagion Clasp.author: Xaxas
227149: Contagion Clasp.text_parsed:
@gos

As can be explained by looking at this(http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/eventcoverage/gpchi09/blog2#5), you will note that the circles of protection have the wording "choose", or "choice". This means that the player decides the recipient of the effect. It is not targeted, so permanents that have shroud or some variant thereof can be affected by them. "target" is not required in a card such as contagion clasp.

227151: Pentavus.author: Psuedonaut
227151: Pentavus.text_parsed:
Ah, uhm... Well, you see.... uhh....

Ashnod's Altar + Doubling Season + This. Let me show you.

Pentavus: 5 counters Tokens: 0 Mana: 1
Pentavus -1(ability) +1(+1 from DS) -1(ability cost)
Pentavus: 4 counters Tokens: 2 Mana: 0
Ashnod's Altar -1(sacrifice cost) +2
Pentavus: 4 counters Tokens: 1 Mana: 2
Pentavus +1(+1 from DS) -1(ability) -1(ability cost)
Pentavus: 6 counters Tokens: 0 Mana: 1

Back where we started, but we have an extra counter. Assuming we follow that loop infinitely, it becomes

Pentavus: Infinite Tokens: 0 Mana: 1
Pentavus -1 +1(+1 from DS) -1
Pentavus: Infinite -1 Tokens: 2 Mana: 0
Ashnod's Altar -2 +4
Pentavus: Infinite -1 Tokens: 0 Mana: 4
Pentavus -1 +1(+1 from DS) -1
Pentavus: Infinite -2 Tokens: 2 Mana: 3
Pentavus +1(+1 from DS) -1 -1
Pentavus: Infinite Tokens: 1 Mana: 2

And now you see that both the tokens and mana ended up 1 more than before, while Pentavus stayed the same. So, in essence, Pentavus is an Infinite/Infinite, you have Infinite 1/1 tokens, and you have Infinite colorless mana. I should ALSO mention, those tokens hit the graveyard and trigger any creature goes to the graveyard or creature enters battlefield effect. And his Infinite/Infinite strength is due to +1/+1 counters.
